title: Alginate based microcapsules for local probiotic delivery: Evaluation of bacterial entrapment, release, and growth

author: Janja Mirtič, Fakulteta za farmacijo, Univerza v Ljubljani

segmentation: Hello also in my name I'm Yanni.
I'm coming from the Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Ljubljana, here in Slovenia.
I'm a bit.

Out of the biophysics expertise, but I always like to come to this conference is because I got some new ideas, so take this lecture as an opportunity to find something to apply your methods to, to analyze this even in more depth.
So today I'll talk about alginate based microcapsules for local delivery of probiotics and.
So I'll focus more on the evaluation of bacteria and treatment release and growth.
So I'll quickly go through the introduction which disease we're dealing with and why.
Microcapsules is delivery systems than methods of production and characterization results in the key messages.
So.
Why I think you all need to be concerned about this topic is because periodontal disease is the disease that will affect.
I think most or all of us, including me during our lifetime.
The problem is that this is a chronic inflammatory disease which starts with a bacterial infections.
Uh, usually the cause.
The main causes the microbial imbalance, so there is a overgrowth of the periodontal pathogenic bacteria and not enough of good bacteria in our oral cavity.
This infections then cause the localized inflammatory response in.
This inflammation has then detrimental effects on the all the surrounding tissues on all the parodontal tissues and in the worst case this leads to a tooth loss.
So we propose, since the standard therapy is very ineffective, usually all the people who receive the standard therapy, which includes plaque removal and antibiotic treatment.
Get the disease so disease reoccur in a period of one year.
So we propose probiotics so helpful bacteria to apply them locally into periodontal pockets.
Since the these pockets, which are formed during the disease, presents some kind of a perfect spot to treat to target the disease.
And we try to develop delivery system for this probiotics.
So during my part of this research we developed alginate microcapsules.
We use alginate because it's a natural derived polysaccharides.
Very abundant and it has a really neat properties that it can be complexed with calcium ions.
So the high hydrogels are formed.
And in this alginate solution we can easily incorporate probiotic bacteria and other excipients, and then just prelim.
So really we use drilling.
This is a method where we extrude the slammer or liquid jet and then with the membrane vibration technology we produce these small droplets when there and then we are collecting them.
When calcium chloride and this still wet microcapsules are formed.
Uh, this microcapsules have done because of alginate negative charge and can be easily coated with oppositely charged polymers.
So Kitas, and just because of the electrostatic interaction.
So, in this way, we get two kinds of capsules.
So when are calcium alginate and one are the same, just with coated with titles and?
Um?
So probiotics that were use are still model probiotics.
They were they were isolated from the oral microflora of healthy volunteers and were characterized with some probiotic activity.
But they need to be further approved.
Oh so.
Methods of characterization.
Most because I'm coming from the Department of Pharmaceutical Technology, we're mostly dealing with the development of the delivery system and then physical chemical characterization.
An in this part in the collaboration with the Institute of Years of Steven, the Environmental Scientists.
We also characterize rise the microbiological parts, so I will focus more on this today.
Um?
OK, if I go shortly also.

So for this measurements of the microbial activity, this special Taylor Mate microscope other chambers were made which enabled us to put this microcapsules into the Agar to provide nutrient rich environment so this probiotics could be done, grown and observed life.
Um, OK so?
So shortly.
The results one quick picture of from the scanning electron microscopy.
So these are two kinds of microcapsules that in the first row it's just calcium alginate and the second coated with titles, and we show that with Ham.

One thing that I forgot to mention to increase the stability of probiotics in these capsules, we Additionally lyophilizer them so we drive them because in what state the probiotics will start to grow and divide already when there are produced.
So we.
Basically, freeze them so they stop so the product.
Then when it's dry looks a bit.

Misshapen otherwise this capsule when they are rehydrated get again the round form OK, so in the first row alginate, which has a quite round surface but with titles and coating we get this irregular surface which is a bit more porous and this also results in higher surface area.
We also quantify how much probiotics we could incorporate.
We get 10 to the 8th of colony forming units.
When we used a vacuum.
Vegatative sells an 10 to the 10th of colony forming units.
When we used sports for the incorporation, we also showed the stability effect of Incapsula Shun because if we followed the stability in the fridge of the life lies probiotic.
Alone it was constantly dropping in comparison with the ones incorporated in microcapsules.
So this is the first video.
Uh, where we wanted to show the spatial distribution of microcaps of probiotics in microcapsules.
This is important because the if aggregates of cells are appearing in this capsules.
The inward diffusion of nutrients, nutrients and oxygen's is lower, which is not good for the growth of the cells and violator viability.
So in our case it's not really visible but OK, we achieved quite good.
Um, good homogenity do throughout the capsule.
In both case of capsules so.
If I go to the next one, so with this microscopic chambers we tried to follow the revival and growth of this bacteria.
So firstly, the microcapsules need to be rehydrated.
Then the cells started to divide it and build up in the capsules and then going out of the capsules and then spread over the surface.
There are several different cases how this happens.
This is just one of them.
So for example, when we have just calcium alginate microcapsules, the cells are not feeling any restrictions, so they basically engulf the alginate and grow all over the place.
But when we have discitis encoding, so another window.
When we have this Skype token code coating, cells are dividing and growing, but they are staying inside the capsule, so there must be some kind of a rupture of the membrane to for them to get out.
So we showed on many.

We showed that there are many different options how this appears, so here for example, these are encapsulated sports, so these white dots are sports and basically they escaped during this whole before they start germinate ING and growing so they are invading the outer space so the surface before they are basically in a life form an they're probably going out in.
Such arose because we also included lactose and glycerol and there is some kind of osmotic effect in other cases.
For example here there was a small rupturing the membrane and the cells then start to go in.
Some small spaces out.
Uh, so.
At the end, in each case the South.
There is not a lot of them needed, so they start to divide.
They basically occupy all the empty spaces between the microcapsules and they grow efficiently.
And as I showed before in case of just alginate.
Last week the they basically engulf also the capsule and they just grow all over the place.
The only difference here, the difference that we showed with these titles encoding is that we can basically in some way stop them from invading the surrounding too soon or soon.
And this was also shown in some.
Um measurements of optical density.
So we are following the growth by measuring optical density and the cells went to the log arhythmic face.
Later, when we applied in the medium titles and coated microcapsules compared to just alginate microcapsules.
We don't try to also show that mycron capsulation's per say and also discuss encoding.

Decoding doesn't have any detrimental effect on the Pro biotic activity, so we followed the growth kinetics of this probiotics and it was pretty much the same in case of both microcapsules or as a comparison with two colorful eyes, probiotics and viable cells.
So the road Connectyx didn't change.
In any of the cases and then we tested its antimicrobial activity.
Because this strain has activity against E. Coli.

So we basically used modified Agar plate method and we showed that in case of microcapsules which are two and four still this small diffusion stones which show that they kill surrounding E. Coli are formed.
So we still have probiotic activity which was not shown.
For the empty microcapsules, and was also shown for the positive control, so lyophilizer bacterion viable cells.
Um so.
So if I just conclude.

Microcapsules based on alginate matrix, an kytos encoding, can be promising delivery system for probiotics and they enable adequate probiotic entrapment, prolong survival viability viability during the encapsulation process enhanced by adhesion potential, modified pro biotic release using the coding and still antibacterial activity.
So the key message would be that we are one step further to a successful.

The periodontal treatment, so hopefully if we get further funding so we are applying this project for the next funding, we will be able to develop also end product for the market with incorporated probiotics.
And yeah, for the final thought.
I want to thank all my coworkers, Faculty of Pharmacy, and Institute for the collaboration and the research agency for the funding and of course, thank you for your.
Patience.
